Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185C.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Housing Court of the City of Boston pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185C and ch. 218, and the Court’s general housing and equity jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes and claims for damages related to breaches of landlord duties and covenants.

ch. 218.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Housing Court of the City of Boston pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185C and ch. 218, and the Court’s general housing and equity jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes and claims for damages related to breaches of landlord duties and covenants.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Tenant generally), including provisions addressing landlord duties, repairs, and tenant remedies.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary Process), including protections against retaliatory evictions under certain circumstances (see, e.g., ch. 239 §§8A, where applicable).

ch. 239 \u00a7\u00a78A.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary Process), including protections against retaliatory evictions under certain circumstances (see, e.g., ch. 239 §§8A, where applicable).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §§127 and related provisions governing public health, housing, and local boards of health enforcement of sanitary code standards.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: - 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation) — setting minimum housing standards and imposing repair obligations.

780 C.M.R..proposition: - 780 C.M.R. (Massachusetts State Building Code) (applicable provisions requiring safe and habitable structures).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Consumer Protection Act) (where applicable to deceptive or unfair practices by landlords; raised here for claim awareness).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 184.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 184 and ch. 185C (procedural and jurisdictional provisions for housing disputes), as applicable.

Devaney v. Zukowski, 352 Mass. 202 (1967.proposition: Selected Massachusetts Cases and Authorities (examples of Massachusetts precedent recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, and protections against retaliation):

Tacoma v. Schuyler, 311 Mass. 321 (1942).proposition: Selected Massachusetts Cases and Authorities (examples of Massachusetts precedent recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, and protections against retaliation):
Tacoma v. Schuyler, 311 Mass. 321 (1942).case_name: Cheetham v. Crescent Gardens Operating Co.
Tacoma v. Schuyler, 311 Mass. 321 (1942).support_reasoning: The case is a premises-liability slip-and-fall decision involving a movie theatre and an invitee, not a landlord‑tenant dispute. It does not discuss covenants of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair obligations, or protections against retaliation, nor does it mention landlord‑tenant doctrines at all. Consequently, it cannot be relied on as Massachusetts precedent for those landlord‑tenant principles.
Tacoma v. Schuyler, 311 Mass. 321 (1942).relevant_excerpt: "The defendant’s duty to the plaintiff as an invitee need not be repeated. See Keenan v. E. M. Loew’s, Inc. 302 Mass. 309, 311. It could have been found that the plaintiff slipped at the spot, the condition of which was described. Although there was evidence that the floor was waxed some time before the night in question, there is no other evidence as to when this was... We are of opinion that the evidence reported did not warrant a finding that the defendant was negligent."

Monroe v. Klein, 377 Mass. 158 (1979).proposition: Selected Massachusetts Cases and Authorities (examples of Massachusetts precedent recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, and protections against retaliation):
Monroe v. Klein, 377 Mass. 158 (1979).case_name: Attorney General v. Collector of Lynn
Monroe v. Klein, 377 Mass. 158 (1979).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether records of real estate tax delinquents are public records under Massachusetts public records law. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, or retaliation protections. Citing Monroe v. Klein for those landlord‑tenant propositions would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
Monroe v. Klein, 377 Mass. 158 (1979).relevant_excerpt:
We reverse and declare that rec­ords of tax delinquents are public records open to inspection.
…
We conclude that the lists of real estate tax delinquents are public records as defined by G. L. c. 4, § 7, Twenty-sixth, and must be open to inspection pursuant to G. L. c. 66, § 10. A declaration should be entered to that effect.

Taddeo v. Phoenix Bay State, 367 Mass. 2.raw_text: Taddeo v. Phoenix Bay State, 367 Mass. 212 (1975)
Taddeo v. Phoenix Bay State, 367 Mass. 2.proposition: Selected Massachusetts Cases and Authorities (examples of Massachusetts precedent recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, and protections against retaliation):
Taddeo v. Phoenix Bay State, 367 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: This case is a criminal prosecution (Commonwealth v. Lykus) about the admissibility of spectrographic voice identification evidence. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, repair duties, or retaliation protections. Accordingly, it cannot serve as Massachusetts precedent for those landlord-tenant propositions.
Taddeo v. Phoenix Bay State, 367 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: In this case of first impression in this Commonwealth, the single issue argued by the defendant concerns the judge's allowing in evidence, from an expert witness introduced by the Commonwealth, opinions as to voice identification based in part on visual analysis of spectrograms, commonly referred to as "voiceprints." We conclude that the evidence was properly admitted.

Thompson v. Naylor, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 35.raw_text: Thompson v. Naylor, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 351 (1980)
Thompson v. Naylor, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 35.proposition: Selected Massachusetts Cases and Authorities (examples of Massachusetts precedent recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair duties, and protections against retaliation):
Thompson v. Naylor, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 35.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal appeal about assault with intent to murder and the application of collateral estoppel/double jeopardy after prior acquittals on firearms charges. It does not address landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, landlord repair obligations, or retaliation protections. Therefore it cannot be cited as Massachusetts precedent on those landlord-tenant doctrines.
Thompson v. Naylor, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 35.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from his convictions of assault with intent to murder while armed with a dangerous weapon... The defendant argues that his acquittals in a District Court on charges of illegal possession of a firearm... precluded the assault conviction. We affirm the judgment.
